Title: Top 10 Live-Action Anime Adaptations That Didn't Understand The Original
Data: www.cbr.com                  CBR Exclusives   Comics   Comics News   Comic Features   Comic Previews   Comic Reviews     Movies    Movie News   Movie Features   Movie Reviews     TV    TV News   TV Features   TV Reviews   Wrestling     Anime   Gaming   Lists   Write For CBR   More   CBR Forums   Buyer's Guides   Nerd Culture   Find a Comic Shop       Follow Us   Follow CBR            Something New                    	Covering the hottest movie and TV topics that fans want.                                      	All the latest gaming news, game reviews and trailers.                                      	A one-stop shop for all things video games.                                           Home Anime Top 10 Live-Action Anime Adaptations That Didn't Understand The Original    Top 10 Live-Action Anime Adaptations That Didn't Understand The Original  By Angelo Delos Trinos Published 23 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   Fans are often disappointed when live-action adaptations deviate from their favorite anime's storyline.                  Adapting an anime to live-action is incredibly tricky – anime and film are two completely different worlds. The best a live-action take can do is capture the spirit of the anime it's bringing to life, but a good number of movies fail in this regard.  RELATED: 5 Anime That Have A Great Live-Action Adaptions (& 5 That Fell Flat) Whether it's misunderstanding the anime's style and themes or deliberately going against everything the original stood for, these live-action adaptations fell short for reasons beyond being unfaithful to the visuals or lore.  10          Bleach Had None Of The Anime's Punk Energy                 For all its flaws, Bleach continues to be a beloved anime because of its punk aesthetic and energy. Whether it was the character designs, episodes' direction, or promotional material, Bleach had a uniquely colorful edge that most anime hope to have. Shinsuke Sato's adaptation, however, dropped all of these stylistic choices.  The live-action Bleach was an urban fantasy that grounded the anime's outlandish moments and world in serious realism. Outside some colorful title cards that disappeared after the first act, the movie had little in the way of anarchic energy. The movie is fairly decent and was even approved by Tite Kubo, but It's nowhere near as wild as it should've been.  9          The Gintama Movies Only Captured The Anime's Costumes & Looks                 Gintama earned its reputation as the gag anime to beat, but almost none of its mastery of humor and parody was reflected in its two live action movies, Gintama and Gintama 2: Rules Are Made To Be Broken. At most, the movies looked more like live-action recreations of the anime's most popular skits as performed by some impressive cosplayers.  Yuichi Fukuda's adaptations were at their best when they made up new jokes and spoofed the fact that they were movies, but these moments were few and far between. Gintama became what it is by making its own brand of comedy separate from the already hilarious manga, but, unfortunately, none of this originality was used for the movies.  8          Lupin The 3rd Had None Of The Anime's Spirit & Originality                 Lupin The Third isn't just a landmark anime, but it's practically an institution as well. The anime, manga's style, and story continue to influence Japanese fiction today, which is why any new adaptation should strive to break new ground as its forerunners did. Unfortunately, Ryuhei Kitamura's critically-panned Lupin The 3rd failed to do so.   RELATED: 5 Anime & Manga Couples That Honestly Shouldn't Be Together At most, all this adaptation had were some text-accurate costumes, poses, and quotes. The movie was as derivative as any uninspired con movie before it, complete with a needlessly convoluted plot that confused confusion for intrigue. By not even trying to do anything new, Lupin The 3rd was just a legendary anime's surface-level reenactment.  7          Kite Was Not As Controversial & Stylish As The OVAs                 Without exaggeration, the Kite OVAs are some of the most controversial anime ever created. Besides the excessive gore, Sawa's time as an assassin was borderline pornographic – so much so that the OVA was banned in certain countries. Understandably, the live-action adaptation toned these parts down or cut them, but lost the original's spirit in doing so.  Ralph Ziman's Kite was as forgettable and pedestrian as a movie about hitmen could get. Worse, it came out at the time when movies starring female assassins like Lucy or Salt were oversaturated. Kite's biggest flaw wasn't its lack of offensive content, but its refusal to be as audacious and stylish as its infamous anime by doing anything risqué.  6          Fist Of The North Star Lacked Its Source Material's Creativity & Scale                 At its heart, Fist Of The North Star is a martial arts-driven tale of revenge. That said, it more than made up for these familiar trappings by pushing everything to the extreme. Not only was the story set in the post-apocalypse, but Kenshiro was the latest master of the Hokuto Shinken style, which granted him the power to make enemies explode.  Few if any of the over-the-top aesthetics made it to the movie, which was as formulaic as a martial arts movie could get. Tony Randel's movie unwisely toned everything down, most egregiously seen in the fights that were nowhere near as bloody and exciting as their animated counterparts. At best, the sets were surprisingly well-made despite the low budget.  5          The Attack On Titan Two-Parter Was A Typical Zombie Apocalypse                 One of the many things that makes Attack On Titan the landmark it is today is that it bears one of the greatest bait-and-switch premises ever told. As it turns out, Paradis Island's war against the Titans wasn't the fight for humanity everyone thought it was, but a dark fate placed on an entire race of people that the world isolated and vilified.  The movies, however, were just another modern-day zombie apocalypse. In brief, the Titans were tall zombies born from failed weapons experiments, and they were stopped with a nuke. Whatever complexity the anime had (especially in themes of militarism, nationalism, racism, etc.) were simplified or dropped in Shinji Higuchi's B-grade two-parter.  4          City Hunter (1993) Was Just Another Jackie Chan Movie                 In the '90s, Jackie Chan became a star by headlining action-comedies about bumbling martial arts heroes who stumbled their way into larger conspiracies. City Hunter fit this bill perfectly, and therein lies the problem. If not for its source material's legacy, Wong Jing's adaptation would be indistinguishable from the likes of Mr. Nice Guy or Rumble In The Bronx.   All City Hunter got right were the characters' names and Ryo Saeba's comedic lechery. Though it had its moments, the movie was more of by-the-numbers Jackie Chan romp than an adaptation. Not helping matters is how City Hunter got the faithfully cartoonish adaptation it deserved in Philippe Lacheau's 2018 movie, which effectively supplanted Chan's.  3          Dragonball: Evolution Was A Highschool Adventure, Not A Galactic Epic                 Part of the reason why Dragon Ball is one of the most influential anime ever made is because of its seemingly bottomless depth of its world and Goku as a person. Goku wasn't just the Monkey King's parallel in this homage to the Chinese epic Journey To The West, he was also an intergalactic warrior, a loving father and friend, and the protector of Earth.  RELATED: Top 10 Worst Ways To Die In Dragon Ball For pragmatic and mostly cynical reasons, James Wong's Dragonball: Evolution scaled everything back. Here, Goku's quest for the Dragon Balls was a coming-of-age story that was more interested in his growth as a teen than the galaxy's defender. The movie didn't just lack the anime's grand scale, but also its stakes and development.  2          Ghost In The Shell Turned The Major Into A Generic Superhero                 Despite starring an iconic action star in Major Motoko Kusanagi, the original Ghost In The Shell was anything but a conventional action story. Instead, it was a meditation about the Major's existential and identity crisis in a technologically dominant world where she's both a cog in an unfeeling inhuman system and a mass-produced cyborg model.  In contrast, Rupert Sanders' movie was the Major's heroic origin story. Here, Major Mira Killian (a cyborg with the brain of the delinquent Motoko Kusanagi) was a one of a kind cyborg super-soldier who fought for justice. Even if it's watchable and momentarily ignoring the twist's racial implications, this movie was formulaic where the anime was anything but.  1          Daily Lives Of Highschool Boys Deconstructed Its Comedy                 In brief, Daigo Matsui's Daily Lives Of Highschool Boys is a deconstruction of the animated sitcom it was based on. The movie adapted some of the anime's most famous jokes and skits, but replaced the punchlines with depressing reality checks. Wacky situations ended with the boys getting reprimanded, or with them contemplating how stupid they acted.  Matsui did this because the manga and anime reminded him of his adolescence but, instead of nostalgia, he felt embarrassment and shame. His adaptation reflected his dour outlook, which undid everything that made the anime funny. Daily Lives Of Highschool Boys was one of the funniest shows of its time, and it deserved a movie better than this.                  10 Anime That Perfectly Balance Action & Comedy  Read Next     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email    Related Topics  Anime bleach ghost in the shell ()     About The Author   Angelo Delos Trinos                                     (414 Articles Published)     CBR Staff Writer Angelo Delos Trinos' professional writing career may have only started a few years ago, but he's been writing and overthinking about anime, comics and movies for his whole life. He probably watched Neon Genesis Evangelion way too much, and he still misses video stores. Follow him at @AD3ofc on Twitter, or email him at delos3nos1992@gmail.com. Title: One-Punch Man: Saitama Reaches Peak Anger
Data: www.cbr.com                  CBR Exclusives   Comics   Comics News   Comic Features   Comic Previews   Comic Reviews     Movies    Movie News   Movie Features   Movie Reviews     TV    TV News   TV Features   TV Reviews   Wrestling     Anime   Gaming   Lists   Write For CBR   More   CBR Forums   Buyer's Guides   Nerd Culture   Find a Comic Shop       Follow Us   Follow CBR            Something New                    	Covering the hottest movie and TV topics that fans want.                                      	All the latest gaming news, game reviews and trailers.                                      	A one-stop shop for all things video games.                                           Home Anime One-Punch Man: Saitama Reaches Peak Anger - for an Unsurprising Reason    One-Punch Man: Saitama Reaches Peak Anger - for an Unsurprising Reason  By Christian Markle Published 2 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   Saitama is known for his lack of emotions in tense situations. In One-Punch Man Chapter 159, he surprisingly expresses immense anger.                  The following contains spoilers for One-Punch Man Chapter 159, "Source of Anxiety," by One, Yusuke Murata, John Werry and James Gaubatz, available in English at Viz Media.   Saitama is known for not being fazed by any threat or danger. He maintains a poker face, even in front of possible Earth-destroying catastrophe -- like when he fought Boros the alien invader or Monster King Orochi. However, that doesn't mean he is an unfeeling robot. There are some cases in which he is actually angered, but only in Chapter 159 has he reached the peak of hatred.  With the amount of power Saitama possesses, there's no longer anything that poses a threat to him. He simply decimates anything that stands in his way with a single punch, hence, the title of the manga. He is, however, not without weaknesses. He is often flustered for missing out on sales and is always problematizing his budget, and the Monster Association's wide-scale attack finally brought out the worst in him. RELATED:Every Giant-Centipede Monster in One-Punch Man (So Far) - and How They Died                 The first question Saitama asked the monsterized Garo was confirmation of his identity, which the Hero Hunter provided. He then launched into a long rant about being the absolute evil, but Saitama was no longer interested in what the monster had to say. Because he deemed Garo not to be a monster, despite the Hero Hunter's admittance, he was convinced there was nothing left for him to do there, leaving Garo surprised and confused..  Before leaving, though, Saitama ranted for a bit, recalling going out of his place to report the recurring noise. However, his house got destroyed, and he now had to go look for his belongings. Saitama expressed his frustration at the situation, claiming he was so angry he could destroy the world. Saitama's outburst wasn't just a bluff, because Garo felt immense pressure when the bald hero made the declaration. RELATED:One-Punch Man: The Hero Association's Strongest Fighter Begins a Godly Task                 Saitama getting angry is a rare occurrence, and this is the first time he reached a world-destroying level of anger. Unsurprisingly, the cause of his fury is not something heavy like losing a friend or witnessing great evil. Rather, it has something to do with his belongings. Saitama has always been concerned about things ordinary individuals will consider trivial -- like supermarket sales and winning against King in a video game. It is, however, interesting to see him express an emotion to that extreme.  Saitama has always been shown to be a calm-headed individual who couldn't feel any sense of danger, so seeing him in a fit of immense rage is a rare occurrence. If there's any moral lesson this teaches the audience, then it's that nobody should mess with Saitama's belongings under any circumstances. Title: One-Punch Man: Saitama Reaches Peak Anger
Data: Home Anime One-Punch Man: Saitama Reaches Peak Anger - for an Unsurprising Reason    One-Punch Man: Saitama Reaches Peak Anger - for an Unsurprising Reason  By Christian Markle Published 2 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   Saitama is known for his lack of emotions in tense situations. In One-Punch Man Chapter 159, he surprisingly expresses immense anger.                  The following contains spoilers for One-Punch Man Chapter 159, "Source of Anxiety," by One, Yusuke Murata, John Werry and James Gaubatz, available in English at Viz Media.   Saitama is known for not being fazed by any threat or danger. He maintains a poker face, even in front of possible Earth-destroying catastrophe -- like when he fought Boros the alien invader or Monster King Orochi. However, that doesn't mean he is an unfeeling robot. There are some cases in which he is actually angered, but only in Chapter 159 has he reached the peak of hatred.  With the amount of power Saitama possesses, there's no longer anything that poses a threat to him. He simply decimates anything that stands in his way with a single punch, hence, the title of the manga. He is, however, not without weaknesses. He is often flustered for missing out on sales and is always problematizing his budget, and the Monster Association's wide-scale attack finally brought out the worst in him. Title: Is Kiyo in Kyoto Entertainment or Education?
Data: www.cbr.com                  CBR Exclusives   Comics   Comics News   Comic Features   Comic Previews   Comic Reviews     Movies    Movie News   Movie Features   Movie Reviews     TV    TV News   TV Features   TV Reviews   Wrestling     Anime   Gaming   Lists   Write For CBR   More   CBR Forums   Buyer's Guides   Nerd Culture   Find a Comic Shop       Follow Us   Follow CBR            Something New                    	Covering the hottest movie and TV topics that fans want.                                      	All the latest gaming news, game reviews and trailers.                                      	A one-stop shop for all things video games.                                           Home Anime Is Kiyo in Kyoto Entertainment or Education?    Is Kiyo in Kyoto Entertainment or Education?  By CBR Staff Published 3 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   Kiyo in Kyoto is a show dedicated to teaching about Japanese culture, so can it also be entertaining?                 Kiyo in Kyoto: From the Maiko House is a lesser-known anime that came out at the tail end of the 2021 winter season. As it was produced by NHK World-Japan, the show walks a fine line between being just a means of entertainment and a means of education. There's only one way to find out whether it's more for entertainment or education, and that's by looking at the contents of the show.  However, before diving into the information given throughout the show, it's good to have an understanding of the context of Kiyo In Kyoto. The series follows Kiyo and her friend Sumire, who are both from Aomori Prefecture and want to become maiko (traditional Japanese entertainers found in Kyoto). While Sumire goes on to train and becomes a maiko, the titular character becomes the cook for that maiko house instead. The show then goes on to cover information about both maiko and Japanese food culture. As the show is produced by NHK World-Japan, the international version of the well-known Japanese broadcasting news and entertainment site, it would make sense that Kiyo in Kyoto is all about culture.  RELATED: Restaurant to Another World Vol. 1 Puts Iyashikei Into Isekai                 It's time to dive into the cultural aspects of the show, starting with the way it depicts the life of maiko. The series mainly takes place in the titular maiko house in the area of Kyoto called Kagai, where all the maiko and their housemothers live together. The show takes viewers along Sumire's journey in becoming a maiko, showing the training process with many tidbits of cultural information. It talks about the processes such as the classes maiko take to learn song and dance, as well as differences between maiko in training and maiko who have already made their "debut". One of these differences is the type of sash or obi the girls wear.  As seen in Episode 4, it shows how a senior apprentice who has not yet debuted wears a "half dangling sash," while a full maiko wears a longer "dangling sash." In that same episode, Sumire gets to debut as full-fledged maiko and gets her maiko name -- Momohana -- which they explain can be chosen in many ways. They can choose the Japanese characters for the maiko's name is by taking inspiration from their real names, from the maiko house they live in or even having it divined for them at a shrine. Along with all the information within the show, there is also a separate short video produced by NHK World-Japan called "Maiko [Maiko-san Chi no Makanai-san - Kiyo in Kyoto: From the Maiko House] - 3-minute Maiko," available on YouTube, where real-life maiko are showcased.  RELATED: How Assassination Classroom Offers a Glimpse at Japan's Educational System Another topic that's discussed a lot in Kiyo in Kyoto is food, which means there's also a lot of information and facts about food not only from Kyoto or Aomori but from all around Japan. The episodes are formatted around the food featured in their respective segment, as each episode is generally formatted into three parts, each a chapter of the manga featuring one main food. Then, after each segment, there are little "talking heads" segments, where Kiyo and Sumire, as well as sometimes their senior Tsurukoma, talk about the food they ate in that segment as well as their regional counterparts.  This segment is called "Sumire and Kiyo's Dish of the Day." A good example of the regional differences discussed during these scenes can be seen in the last segment of Episode 5, where the series talks about different soups from across Japan. It starts with the soup that was featured in the episode -- hittsumi soup from Aomori -- and goes on to talk about soups from other places, such as teppo soup from Hokkaido, natto soup from Yamagata and itoko soup from Kyoto. This kind of cultural analysis in these segments is common and very educational.                  Of course, to be an anime, the show must be entertaining as well, and entertaining it is. Kiyo in Kyoto has no lack of cute characters and scenes. Not everything in the show is meant to teach the viewer; it also contains a plot and characters that grow throughout, as well as numerous cute and fluffy scenes. The show can have both entertainment and educational elements within it, as many shows do. So, to answer whether Kiyo in Kyoto: From the Maiko House is an entertainment or an education series, it's happily both.                   Heaven's Design Team Mixes 'Edutainment' With... Creationism? Title: Shield Hero: Who Is the Melromarc Kingdom's True Ruler?
Data: www.cbr.com                  CBR Exclusives   Comics   Comics News   Comic Features   Comic Previews   Comic Reviews     Movies    Movie News   Movie Features   Movie Reviews     TV    TV News   TV Features   TV Reviews   Wrestling     Anime   Gaming   Lists   Write For CBR   More   CBR Forums   Buyer's Guides   Nerd Culture   Find a Comic Shop       Follow Us   Follow CBR            Something New                    	Covering the hottest movie and TV topics that fans want.                                      	All the latest gaming news, game reviews and trailers.                                      	A one-stop shop for all things video games.                                           Home Anime Shield Hero: Who Is the True Ruler of Melromarc?    Shield Hero: Who Is the True Ruler of Melromarc?  By Louis Kemner Published 22 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   One specific character is the true boss of the Melromarc kingdom in The Rising of the Shield Hero - and an ally of Naofumi's.                 The Rising of the Shield Hero is a grim but exciting isekai anime starring the unfortunate protagonist Iwatani Naofumi, the titular shield-bearing hero who must save the Melromarc kingdom from Waves of monsters. At first it seemed no one in the royal court was on Naofumi's side, but that soon changed when the queen showed up.  Naofumi had a terrible experience with King Aultclay XXXII and his daughter, Princess Malty, but Queen Mirellia Melromarc is a different story. Her worldview and policies differ greatly from her scheming husband's, and she played a much bigger role in the later sequences of Season 1. This may continue well into Season 2 of Shield Hero as well. RELATED: Meet The Rising of the Shield Hero's Main Characters          The Fair Rule Of Queen Mirellia Melromarc                Shield Hero's Melromarc kingdom is a matrilineal nation, meaning the royal bloodline is carried through the women while men such as Aultclay marry into the family. This means Queen Mirellia wields the most power in Melromarc, but when Naofumi arrived with the other three Cardinal Heroes, she was nowhere to be seen. This led to a bad start for Naofumi's adventure, since King Aultclay and Princess Malty were scheming with the Church of Three Heroes to tarnish the Shield Hero's name forever. This scheme could have been uncovered and dealt with much sooner had the queen been there, since she is a fair and honorable ruler who doesn't share her husband and elder daughter's hatred of the Shield Hero.  There's more than a personal difference between the queen, king and elder princess, however. The three royals are split because of international and race politics as well, all based on the presence of demi-humans in the Melromarc kingdom and the historic role of the Shield Hero. In previous eras, the Shield Hero was a symbol of hope for the demi-humans, and in the modern era, Mirellia is also sympathetic to both parties rather than being prejudiced against anyone. This is why she accepted the tanuki-like Raphtalia as the Shield Hero's companion without complaint. Unlike the rest of the royal family, Mirellia -- and her younger daughter Melty -- seek to unite the four heroes and make use of the Shield Hero, rather than ostracize him because of race relations between humans and demi-humans. Queen Mirellia is a symbol of hope and tolerance in the eyes of demi-humans, which puts her at odds with her family and even the non-Shield heroes at times. But as Season 1 of Shield Hero showed, this all set her up as Naofumi's most powerful ally.  RELATED: How the Shield Hero Anime Refined the Isekai Harem Concept          How Queen Mirellia Aided Naofumi In Shield Hero Season 1                Queen Mirellia didn't appear at first in The Rising of the Shield Hero, but did make some cameo appearances along with her Shadow agents until being formally introduced later on. Mirellia helped uncover the Church of Three Heroes' plot with the king, and personally oversaw the trial where King Aultclay and Princess Malty were found guilty of conspiracy. Given Mirellia's influence and the quality of her investigation into the matter, this helped clear Naofumi's name beyond all about -- even the oafish Motoyasu was forced to recognize the Queen's words and turn against Malty. Mirellia was even prepared to execute the king and princess until Naofumi intervened and decided to punish them with humiliation and a loss of authority instead.  RELATED: Shield Hero: The Berserk-Style Power of Naofumi's Rage Shield Mirellia came to Naofumi's aid soon after the would-be "beach episode" at the Cal Mira archipelago, when an unexpected Wave arrived. Unlike the previous Waves, this would be a naval battle, and Mirellia personally led a small fleet of warships and soldiers to aid the four Cardinal Heroes in battle against a series of sea monsters. The queen proved her worth as a leader of men in that battle, commanding her fleet with a steady hand as the Cardinal Heroes took the lead against the Wave's strongest monsters.  The battle was a success, and Queen Mirellia will continue to aid Naofumi however she can against future Waves and other quests in Season 2. With a further authority to mobilize the other three Cardinal Heroes to help, Mirella is now poised to take center stage alongside Naofumi as Shield Hero continues.                  The Best Anime to Watch After The Rising of the Shield Hero  Read Next     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email    Related Topics  Anime the rising of the shield hero     About The Author   Louis Kemner                                     (3956 Articles Published)     Louis Kemner has been a fan of Japanese animation since 1997, when he discovered Pokemon and Dragon Ball Z in elementary school. Now he's a bigger anime/manga fan than ever, and is ready to share what he knows with readers worldwide. Title: Shield Hero: Who Is the Melromarc Kingdom's True Ruler?
Data: Home Anime Shield Hero: Who Is the True Ruler of Melromarc?    Shield Hero: Who Is the True Ruler of Melromarc?  By Louis Kemner Published 22 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   One specific character is the true boss of the Melromarc kingdom in The Rising of the Shield Hero - and an ally of Naofumi's.                 The Rising of the Shield Hero is a grim but exciting isekai anime starring the unfortunate protagonist Iwatani Naofumi, the titular shield-bearing hero who must save the Melromarc kingdom from Waves of monsters. At first it seemed no one in the royal court was on Naofumi's side, but that soon changed when the queen showed up.  Naofumi had a terrible experience with King Aultclay XXXII and his daughter, Princess Malty, but Queen Mirellia Melromarc is a different story. Her worldview and policies differ greatly from her scheming husband's, and she played a much bigger role in the later sequences of Season 1. This may continue well into Season 2 of Shield Hero as well. RELATED: Meet The Rising of the Shield Hero's Main Characters          The Fair Rule Of Queen Mirellia Melromarc                Shield Hero's Melromarc kingdom is a matrilineal nation, meaning the royal bloodline is carried through the women while men such as Aultclay marry into the family. This means Queen Mirellia wields the most power in Melromarc, but when Naofumi arrived with the other three Cardinal Heroes, she was nowhere to be seen. This led to a bad start for Naofumi's adventure, since King Aultclay and Princess Malty were scheming with the Church of Three Heroes to tarnish the Shield Hero's name forever. This scheme could have been uncovered and dealt with much sooner had the queen been there, since she is a fair and honorable ruler who doesn't share her husband and elder daughter's hatred of the Shield Hero.  There's more than a personal difference between the queen, king and elder princess, however. The three royals are split because of international and race politics as well, all based on the presence of demi-humans in the Melromarc kingdom and the historic role of the Shield Hero. In previous eras, the Shield Hero was a symbol of hope for the demi-humans, and in the modern era, Mirellia is also sympathetic to both parties rather than being prejudiced against anyone. This is why she accepted the tanuki-like Raphtalia as the Shield Hero's companion without complaint. Unlike the rest of the royal family, Mirellia -- and her younger daughter Melty -- seek to unite the four heroes and make use of the Shield Hero, rather than ostracize him because of race relations between humans and demi-humans. Queen Mirellia is a symbol of hope and tolerance in the eyes of demi-humans, which puts her at odds with her family and even the non-Shield heroes at times. But as Season 1 of Shield Hero showed, this all set her up as Naofumi's most powerful ally.  RELATED: How the Shield Hero Anime Refined the Isekai Harem Concept          How Queen Mirellia Aided Naofumi In Shield Hero Season 1                Queen Mirellia didn't appear at first in The Rising of the Shield Hero, but did make some cameo appearances along with her Shadow agents until being formally introduced later on. Mirellia helped uncover the Church of Three Heroes' plot with the king, and personally oversaw the trial where King Aultclay and Princess Malty were found guilty of conspiracy. Given Mirellia's influence and the quality of her investigation into the matter, this helped clear Naofumi's name beyond all about -- even the oafish Motoyasu was forced to recognize the Queen's words and turn against Malty. Mirellia was even prepared to execute the king and princess until Naofumi intervened and decided to punish them with humiliation and a loss of authority instead.  RELATED: Shield Hero: The Berserk-Style Power of Naofumi's Rage Shield Mirellia came to Naofumi's aid soon after the would-be "beach episode" at the Cal Mira archipelago, when an unexpected Wave arrived. Unlike the previous Waves, this would be a naval battle, and Mirellia personally led a small fleet of warships and soldiers to aid the four Cardinal Heroes in battle against a series of sea monsters. The queen proved her worth as a leader of men in that battle, commanding her fleet with a steady hand as the Cardinal Heroes took the lead against the Wave's strongest monsters.  The battle was a success, and Queen Mirellia will continue to aid Naofumi however she can against future Waves and other quests in Season 2. With a further authority to mobilize the other three Cardinal Heroes to help, Mirella is now poised to take center stage alongside Naofumi as Shield Hero continues. Title: How Dr. Stone's Senku Became the Batman of Shonen Anime
Data: www.cbr.com                  CBR Exclusives   Comics   Comics News   Comic Features   Comic Previews   Comic Reviews     Movies    Movie News   Movie Features   Movie Reviews     TV    TV News   TV Features   TV Reviews   Wrestling     Anime   Gaming   Lists   Write For CBR   More   CBR Forums   Buyer's Guides   Nerd Culture   Find a Comic Shop       Follow Us   Follow CBR            Something New                    	Covering the hottest movie and TV topics that fans want.                                      	All the latest gaming news, game reviews and trailers.                                      	A one-stop shop for all things video games.                                           Home Anime How Dr. Stone Secretly Became Shonen's Batman    How Dr. Stone Secretly Became Shonen's Batman  By Louis Kemner Published 1 day ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   Dr. Stone protagonist Ishigami Senku is a heroic investigator and inventor with surprising similarities to Batman.                 Dr. Stone is an edutainment anime series taking place in a far-future Stone Age where human civilization has long since rusted away, yielding to a primitive world of stone and the rule of the strong. Protagonist Ishigami Senku has other ideas, however. As a hopeful shonen hero, he's certain he can bring civilization back and usher in a better future.  Overall, Senku has little overlap with more traditional shonen heroes such as the rubbery pirate Luffy or even the sorcerer Itadori Yuji. Instead, Dr. Stone's lead is more like shonen's Batman -- without the gothic themes or personal angst. Senku is a merciful, resourceful and law-oriented hero who fights brutal villains with brains instead of brawn, making him worthy of any DC comic title. RELATED: How Science Fell in Love Became a Battle Shonen Anime          How Senku Built His Own Bat Family In Dr. Stone                Dr. Stone's Senku has many startling parallels with the Dark Knight, even if their personalities, settings and personal backstories differ greatly. In fact, not only is Senku a surprisingly accurate anime analog for Batman, he even has an entire Bat Family of his own: a group of trustworthy friends who all work together to help get the job done right.  To begin with, Senku recruited the curious "sorcerer" Chrome, who soon became his enthusiastic scientist apprentice similar to Batman taking on Jason Todd/Robin as his sidekick. Like Robin, Chrome is largely content to play second fiddle -- though he sometimes enjoys showing off his inventions, including re-creating 21st century devices without even realizing it. Senku then recruited his own Catwoman, the agile warrior/hunter Kohaku, who is personally loyal to him but also committed to her own cause. In this case, Kohaku has strong ties to her native Ishigami Village and her elder sister Ruri, the village priestess. Just the way Catwoman is sometimes Batman's ally and lover, Kohaku helps Senku whenever she can, though their relationship is largely platonic.  RELATED: Dr. Stone's Final Chapter Turns Senku Into Terminator's John Connor Senku, as the Stone Age Batman, also has his own Lucius Fox: the elderly craftsman Kaseki, who can build just about anything. Just the way Lucius helps Batman purchase or create new weapons and gadgets, Kaseki aids Senku by expertly crafting items such as glass flasks and thin strands of gold wire, and indeed, Senku wouldn't have gotten very far without him. Batman is an expert at using his tools, but not even he can invent everything himself. Finally, Senku gathered all these allies into his own bat cave -- his Kingdom of Science -- complete with its own flag. This secluded miniature kingdom was kept apart from Ishigami Village and Tsukasa's Empire of Might, which could each be considered Gotham City. Senku is committed to uniting all people under his banner of justice to create a better future, but he can only do so if he keeps his distance and can work in secret. Every hero needs their own bat cave.  RELATED: Nami and Kalifa Battle in New One Piece Illustration By Dr. Stone Artist          Ishigami Senku As Batman In Dr. Stone                 Many facets of Senku's character and various scenes or instances in Dr. Stone clearly establish him as the Batman of modern shonen. He's a crafty inventor who relies on brains rather than brawn to defeat his mighty foes, and he shares Batman's sense of mercy and compassion. Neither will take a life for any reason, and they aren't too fond of deadly weapons either. Both are stubbornly optimistic that they can bloodlessly defeat their foes to create a better future for all, either in the Stone Age or Gotham, and this has inspired other people to join them with the power of friendship.  By recruiting Chrome as his own Robin and Kohaku as Catwoman, Senku quickly built up his own bat family -- especially when Kaseki joined the crew and, later, the entirety of Ishigami Village. It wasn't easy though; Senku had to fight his own Bane more than once, such as the thuggish Magma and certainly Tsukasa, having to use his Batman-style wits and inventions to win the day without brute force or bloodshed. He and his "bat family" defeated Magma to make Senku the tribe's chief, and that in turn allowed Senku to administer medicine to the afflicted Ruri. The Stone Wars later began, and Senku reinvented walkie talkies and flash-bang grenades to compensate for his team's lack of strength against Tsukasa's own forces. In fact, the Dr. Stone protagonist even created a steam-powered car with bamboo weave tires as a battering ram, thus creating his own Batmobile in the Stone Age to win the day. That's a Batman anime moment if there ever was one. Title: Demon Slayer: What Is Enmu’s Gender?
Data: www.cbr.com                  CBR Exclusives   Comics   Comics News   Comic Features   Comic Previews   Comic Reviews     Movies    Movie News   Movie Features   Movie Reviews     TV    TV News   TV Features   TV Reviews   Wrestling     Anime   Gaming   Lists   Write For CBR   More   CBR Forums   Buyer's Guides   Nerd Culture   Find a Comic Shop       Follow Us   Follow CBR            Something New                    	Covering the hottest movie and TV topics that fans want.                                      	All the latest gaming news, game reviews and trailers.                                      	A one-stop shop for all things video games.                                           Home Anime Demon Slayer: What Is Enmu’s Gender?    Demon Slayer: What Is Enmu’s Gender?  By Jessie Xu Published 21 minutes ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   Enmu has been a mysterious character in Demon Slayer from the start, but one topic has been hotly debated: the demon's gender.                 The most powerful demons in Demon Slayer are called the Twelve Kizuki (Demon Moons), who are further divided into six Upper Ranks and six Lower Ranks. The Lower Ranks were later all slaughtered by Muzan in disdain of their weakness, with the exception of one: Enmu.  Enmu is the Lower Rank One demon, and the primary antagonist in the Mugen Train Arc, who appears as a young man of average height with shoulder-length black hair tinged with pink, and blue eyes that have the kanji for "Lower One" etched into the irises. These neutral features, as well as a slow, drawling voice, can make Enmu's gender seem ambiguous. RELATED: Who Is Upper-Rank One in Demon Slayer?                Despite that, Enmu is, in fact, male -- and one with sadistic tendencies. He is one of the few demons throughout Demon Slayer that appears totally irredeemable, because he enjoys watching the suffering of humans.  His utter devotion to Muzan was also what saved Enmu when faced with impending death. While the rest of the Lower Moons begged for their lives, or tried to save themselves from slaughter, Enmu faced Muzan with an expression of reverence. That deviation was outside of Muzan’s expectations. As a character who enjoys feeling superior, Muzan spared Enmu, and instead gave him more blood -- and another opportunity to prove himself. Enmu took that opportunity, and his newfound power, to hatch a nefarious plot. He merged with the Mugen Train, intending to take its passengers as his victims. Most of Enmu’s skills center around his ability to manipulate dreams and reality. He can put people to sleep in his dream realm and show them beautiful, idealistic visions, or present them with the most heart-wrenching nightmares. It's that dynamic that challenges Tanjiro’s fortitude throughout the Mugen Train Arc.  RELATED: Why Does Muzan Hate Doma of the Twelve Kizuki in Demon Slayer?                When Tanjiro and his companions boarded the train to investigate a series of mysterious disappearances, Enmu dragged them into a dream realm with the intent of killing them in their sleep. However, he cruelly borrowed the hands of four vulnerable children with terminal illnesses to perform that deed, luring them with the promise of an eternity of happy dreams. Tanjiro found himself in a world of peace where his family is alive and well, a reality he had long wished for, but one that he cannot regain. Despite how easy it would have been to simply lose himself in this false but idealistic world, with the assistance of Nezuko, Tanjiro forced himself back to reality.  That is the true cruelty of Enmu. He takes advantage of people’s deepest desires and regrets, and turns it against them. His utter devotion to Muzan, as well as his genuine enjoyment of human suffering, separates him from other demons.                  Demon Slayer: Why Did Muzan Kill Tanjiro's Family? An avid anime fan for as long as she can remember, Jessie likes binge-watching her favourite animes and catching up with seasonal shows. She is a big sucker for beautiful animation and deep stories. It's that dynamic that challenges Tanjiro’s fortitude throughout the Mugen Train Arc.  RELATED: Why Does Muzan Hate Doma of the Twelve Kizuki in Demon Slayer?                When Tanjiro and his companions boarded the train to investigate a series of mysterious disappearances, Enmu dragged them into a dream realm with the intent of killing them in their sleep. However, he cruelly borrowed the hands of four vulnerable children with terminal illnesses to perform that deed, luring them with the promise of an eternity of happy dreams. Tanjiro found himself in a world of peace where his family is alive and well, a reality he had long wished for, but one that he cannot regain. Despite how easy it would have been to simply lose himself in this false but idealistic world, with the assistance of Nezuko, Tanjiro forced himself back to reality.  That is the true cruelty of Enmu. He takes advantage of people’s deepest desires and regrets, and turns it against them. His utter devotion to Muzan, as well as his genuine enjoyment of human suffering, separates him from other demons.                  Demon Slayer: Why Did Muzan Kill Tanjiro's Family? Title: Spy X Family Anime TV Review
Data: www.cbr.com                  CBR Exclusives   Comics   Comics News   Comic Features   Comic Previews   Comic Reviews     Movies    Movie News   Movie Features   Movie Reviews     TV    TV News   TV Features   TV Reviews   Wrestling     Anime   Gaming   Lists   Write For CBR   More   CBR Forums   Buyer's Guides   Nerd Culture   Find a Comic Shop       Follow Us   Follow CBR            Something New                    	Covering the hottest movie and TV topics that fans want.                                      	All the latest gaming news, game reviews and trailers.                                      	A one-stop shop for all things video games.                                           Home Anime Spy x Family Crafts a Heartfelt Adaptation of Tatsuya Endo's Beloved Manga    Spy x Family Crafts a Heartfelt Adaptation of Tatsuya Endo's Beloved Manga  By Michael Lacerna Published 22 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   The new show brings Tatsuya Endo's award-winning manga to life while retaining all of the laughs and warmth that made the original work so special.                 Spy x Family is probably the most hyped-up new show of anime's spring season. It might even be the most anticipated anime debut of 2022. Not only is it an adaptation of one of the most critically acclaimed manga of the last decade, but the anime is also being produced by Wit Studio (Ranking of Kings, Vivy: Fluorite Eyes' Song) and CloverWorks (My Dress-Up Darling, Wonder Egg Priority) -- two of the highest-profile animation studios in Japan. It's an understatement to say that the Spy x Family anime is premiering to extremely high expectations. Thankfully, the first episode of the anime lives up to those lofty expectations and may be one of the rare adaptations that manage to improve its source material.  The first episode of the show introduces viewers to the world-renowned super spy who is only known by his code name, Twilight. After deftly defusing an attempt to smear a powerful politician in the show's intro, Twilight is assigned his most challenging mission ever. This mission requires him to pretend to be an average family man to get close to his next target, a dangerous political leader who only appears in public to attend events held by the prestigious private academy his son attends. In order to infiltrate the school, Twilight takes on the alias "Loid Forger" and adopts a seemingly normal little girl, Anya. Unfortunately for him, his daughter has a secret of her own: she is an escaped experiment with psychic powers, which she immediately uses to discover her new father's double identity.  RELATED: Spy X Family Is Japan's Most Anticipated New Anime The new show manages to perfectly translate the humor from Tatsuya Endo's original manga. From the absurdity of the toupee-based conspiracy in the intro to Anya's reactions whenever she reads her father's purely espionage-focused thoughts, the first episode is loaded with multiple laugh-out-loud moments. There are even a few gags that are improved in the anime, such as the scene where Anya attempts to stealthily follow her super-spy father out of the house. The comedy is also improved thanks to excellent voice acting from Haikyuu's Takuya Eguchi, who perfectly captures Loid's world-weary yet empathetic personality with his performance. Atsumi Tanezaki, who previously starred in Mob Psycho 100, is also perfectly cast as Anya, whom she manages to portray as being adorably naive without being cloying.  Another aspect of the show that is improved with animation is the series' brief action scenes, which are animated with all the smoothness and impact you'd expect from both Wit Studio and CloverWorks. While the animation doesn't quite match the best moments from Vivy: Fluorite Eyes' Song's chaotic battles or the loving attention to detail that was displayed in My Dress-Up Darling, it's still a great-looking show in its own right. Action isn't the focus of the series, but the first episode makes it clear that the team behind the show is more than capable of choreographing and animating an exciting, impactful brawl for the scenes that require Loid to get his hands dirty.  RELATED: Spy X Family Creator Shares Adorable New Art for Series’ Anniversary With that said, the anime wouldn't live up to the award-winning manga if Spy x Family didn't also manage to translate the original work's tangible feelings of warmth and familial tenderness. Thankfully, those key elements of the series appear to have been ported over fully intact. Even within its first episode, it's hard to not feel something when Loid and Anya celebrate their first victories together and show the first hints of a true father-daughter bond. These moments were the most memorable parts of Endo's manga, and they're also the best parts of the anime's premiere episode. In less than half an hour, the show manages to give you an idea of who Loid and Anya really are, and makes you want to see the dysfunctional family succeed.  Judged only on its spot-on comedy and action, Spy x Family would already be in the running for the best series of the last decade, but the series' more heartfelt moments elevate it to potentially being one of the best anime and manga series of all time. If the rest of the season can keep up the level of quality displayed in the first episode, then anime fans are truly in for something special. Spy x Family is being simulcast on Crunchyroll. The original manga is available in English from VIZ Media. After working for several years as a writer and copy editor for companies like an advertising agency and a music label, Michael has come to CBR to pursue his true passion: sharing his love for giant robots and collectible monsters. Title: Doctor Strange 2's Elizabeth Olsen Says It's 'Fun' to Not Always Play the Hero
Data: www.cbr.com                  CBR Exclusives   Comics   Comics News   Comic Features   Comic Previews   Comic Reviews     Movies    Movie News   Movie Features   Movie Reviews     TV    TV News   TV Features   TV Reviews   Wrestling     Anime   Gaming   Lists   Write For CBR   More   CBR Forums   Buyer's Guides   Nerd Culture   Find a Comic Shop       Follow Us   Follow CBR            Something New                    	Covering the hottest movie and TV topics that fans want.                                      	All the latest gaming news, game reviews and trailers.                                      	A one-stop shop for all things video games.                                           Home Movies Doctor Strange 2's Elizabeth Olsen Says It's 'Fun' to Not Always Play the Hero    Doctor Strange 2's Elizabeth Olsen Says It's 'Fun' to Not Always Play the Hero  By Hansini Wasalamudalige Published 10 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   The MCU's Elizabeth Olsen discusses why she enjoys playing a morally ambiguous hero ahead of her appearance as Wanda Maximoff in Doctor Strange 2.                 Doctor Strange in the Multiverse of Madness actor Elizabeth Olsen revealed that she finds Wanda Maximoff a more interesting character to portray than some other Marvel superheroes, thanks to her moral ambiguity.  As reported by The Direct, Olsen shared at the official press release for the upcoming Doctor Strange film that she has really enjoyed playing a morally gray hero. "It’s not the most fun, in my mind, to always play the hero of a story where they do no wrong," she said. "I don’t find that interesting. I think the reason why I really enjoyed Wanda from the beginning is that she’s very clear in her beliefs. They just don’t align with others, and that’s okay. She'll have her own realizations and admit when she makes mistakes." RELATED: Marvel Edits Doctor Strange 2 International Poster Over 'Offensive' Hand Gesture  Olsen is likely referring to the events of last year's Disney+ series, WandaVision, where Wanda took over the entire town of Westview with her magic in order to live out her fantasy of a life with fellow Avenger Vision, who had been killed by Thanos in Avengers: Infinity War. While the series ended with the newly named "Scarlet Witch" freeing the residents of Westview from her spell, the final shot of the series showed Wanda attempting to master the Darkhold, a book of dark magic, presumably to try and bring her family back. Wanda is not the only Avenger who will be on a journey of self-discovery, however. Benedict Cumberbatch, who plays Doctor Strange, also stated that his character will confront versions of himself across the multiverse and learn more about himself in the process. "Strange sees, through his experience in the Multiverse and the various versions of him in the Multiverse, how much of a pattern of behavior he carries," Cumberbatch explained. "It’s a kind of imprint, an identification of who Doctor Stephen Strange is in any universe and what the dangers of that character are. Is he going to be the hero to his enemy or the enemy to his hero? Who is our Doctor Strange in the Multiverse? He’s literally coming up against versions of himself to figure that out."  RELATED: America Chavez Co-Creator Slams Marvel's 'Insulting' Doctor Strange 2 Offer Directed by Sam Raimi, Doctor Strange in the Multiverse of Madness takes place a few months after the events of Spider-Man: No Way Home, with Dr. Stephen Strange and his team venturing into the multiverse to face a new enemy who threatens to tear the fabric of their world wide open. Alongside Cumberbatch and Olsen, the film also features Benedict Wong, Chiwetel Ejiofor, Xochitl Gomez, Michael Stuhlbarg and Rachel McAdams. Doctor Strange in the Multiverse of Madness is set to be released in theaters on May 6.  Source: Press release via The Direct                  Doctor Strange 2 Is the Perfect Opportunity to Resurrect Quicksilver  Read Next     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email    Related Topics  Movies Doctor Strange 2     About The Author      Hansini Wasalamudalige                                     (94 Articles Published)     CBR Anime News Writer Hansini Wasalamudalige majored in Professional and Creative Writing for her Bachelor of Arts from Deakin University (Australia). She has been a fan of anime and manga for over a decade, with the original Yu-Gi-Oh! being her gateway into both mediums. Her favourite series include Fullmetal Alchemist, Fruits Basket and Black Butler. When Hansini is not obsessing fuelling her otaku tendencies, she loves to write, play video games and hang out with friends. Title: Doctor Strange 2's Elizabeth Olsen Says It's 'Fun' to Not Always Play the Hero
Data: Hansini Wasalamudalige                                     (94 Articles Published)     CBR Anime News Writer Hansini Wasalamudalige majored in Professional and Creative Writing for her Bachelor of Arts from Deakin University (Australia). She has been a fan of anime and manga for over a decade, with the original Yu-Gi-Oh! being her gateway into both mediums. Her favourite series include Fullmetal Alchemist, Fruits Basket and Black Butler. When Hansini is not obsessing fuelling her otaku tendencies, she loves to write, play video games and hang out with friends.  More                     From Hansini Wasalamudalige

Ken Kaneki's hair changes color multiple times throughout the Tokyo Ghoul and Tokyo Ghoul:re manga. There are two reasons that explain this. Hayley McCullough    Hayley is a News Writer for CBR. In 2021, she earned her PhD in Communication & Rhetoric from Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute and currently works in the Department of Communication, Liberal Arts, and Social Sciences at New Mexico Tech. Her research examines the linguistic structure of storytelling and pop culture. Title: Lady Gaga, Crunchyroll Team Up for New Apparel Collection
Data: www.cbr.com                  CBR Exclusives   Comics   Comics News   Comic Features   Comic Previews   Comic Reviews     Movies    Movie News   Movie Features   Movie Reviews     TV    TV News   TV Features   TV Reviews   Wrestling     Anime   Gaming   Lists   Write For CBR   More   CBR Forums   Buyer's Guides   Nerd Culture   Find a Comic Shop       Follow Us   Follow CBR            Something New                    	Covering the hottest movie and TV topics that fans want.                                      	All the latest gaming news, game reviews and trailers.                                      	A one-stop shop for all things video games.                                           Home Anime Lady Gaga, Crunchyroll Team Up for New Apparel Collection    Lady Gaga, Crunchyroll Team Up for New Apparel Collection  By Hayley McCullough Published 20 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   Lady Gaga and Crunchyroll are teaming up to create a special streetwear clothing collection that features an anime version of the iconic pop star.                    Musical icon Lady Gaga received an anime makeover thanks to a new partnership with Crunchyroll.  According to an official press release, pre-orders for the special Crunchyroll Loves x Lady Gaga streetwear collection will be available through April 21, exclusively through the streaming service's online store. Featuring imagery inspired by the singer's sixth studio album, Chromatica, and artwork from McFlyy, the collection has a total of eight pieces, including multiple t-shirts and hoodies, a pair of back fleece joggers, a bucket hat and a beanie. The Born This Way Foundation, Lady Gaga's non-profit that focuses on improving mental health and making the world a happier place, will receive a portion of the total proceeds.  RELATED: 3 Classic Dragon Ball Anime Series Join Crunchyroll’s Lineup   6 Images                   Expand                    Expand                    Expand                    Expand                    Expand                    Expand      Close          Chromatica made its debut in May 2020 and has a cyberpunk-inspired aesthetic. Synthesizers, percussion and orchestral arrangements feature throughout the score, and other musical icons like Elton John and Blackpink collaborated on some of the album's tracks. It went on to win multiple awards, including Best Pop Duo/Group Performance for "Rain on Me" at the 63rd Annual Grammy Awards and Western Album of the Year at the Japan Gold Disc Awards in 2021. The Crunchyroll Loves x Lady Gaga collection isn't the only new thing that can be found on the streaming service's website; several new anime series are currently making their premieres as part of the spring 2022 lineup. This includes Spy x Family, Love After World Domination, Skeleton Knight in Another World and The Greatest Demon Lord is Reborn by a Typical Nobody.  RELATED: Jujutsu Kaisen 0 Teams Up With Uniqlo for New Graphic Tee Collection Multiple fan-favorite shows are making their return on Crunchyroll as well. Most notably, the second season of the iconic isekai anime, The Rising of the Shield Hero, is finally airing after the first season ended back in 2019. Crunchyroll is also streaming new seasons of Ascendance of a Bookworm and Magia Record: Puella Magi Madoka Magica Side Story. The anime streaming giant recently removed over fifty titles from its catalog. The removal included both popular series, like Is It Wrong to Pick Up Girls in a Dungeon?, Food Wars: Shogeki No Shoma, Akame ga Kill! and No Game No Life, as well as more obscure shows, like Sunday Without God, The Pet Girl of Sakurasou, Is The Order a Rabbit?, Infinite Stratos and Familiar of Zero F. While no official explanation for the animes' removal was provided by Crunchyroll, it is noteworthy that the majority of the titles are licensed by Sentai Filmworks, which owns the competing anime streaming service, HIDIVE.  Source: Press Release                  Shojo Demand Is Surpassing Available Anime Franchises, Says Crunchyroll  Read Next     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email    Related Topics  Anime Crunchyroll     About The Author      Hayley McCullough                                     (444 Articles Published)     Hayley is a News Writer for CBR. In 2021, she earned her PhD in Communication & Rhetoric from Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute and currently works in the Department of Communication, Liberal Arts, and Social Sciences at New Mexico Tech. Her research examines the linguistic structure of storytelling and pop culture. She can often be found marathoning horror movies instead of sleeping, playing puzzle games, and reading a probably unhealthy amount of fanfiction. Title: 10 Dragon Ball Rematches That’ll Never Happen At This Point
Data: www.cbr.com                  CBR Exclusives   Comics   Comics News   Comic Features   Comic Previews   Comic Reviews     Movies    Movie News   Movie Features   Movie Reviews     TV    TV News   TV Features   TV Reviews   Wrestling     Anime   Gaming   Lists   Write For CBR   More   CBR Forums   Buyer's Guides   Nerd Culture   Find a Comic Shop       Follow Us   Follow CBR            Something New                    	Covering the hottest movie and TV topics that fans want.                                      	All the latest gaming news, game reviews and trailers.                                      	A one-stop shop for all things video games.                                           Home Lists 10 Dragon Ball Rematches That’ll Never Happen At This Point    10 Dragon Ball Rematches That’ll Never Happen At This Point  By Daniel Kurland Published 1 hour ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   Dragon Ball fans would love to see a sequel to their favorite battles. Unfortunately, some characters won't ever get a rematch.                  Akira Toriyama’s Dragon Ball has achieved legendary status that’s kept it at the forefront of the anime industry for nearly four decades. Dragon Ball chronicles the heroic adventures of Goku and his courageous friends who tirelessly fight to protect the planet from danger. There’s a huge cast, incredible energy techniques, and powerful transformations that keep Dragon Ball fresh, but the series always knows when to expand its boundaries and head into new territory.  RELATED: Dragon Ball: 10 Fights That Dragged On Too Long The thrilling battles that punctuate Dragon Ball’s climaxes are one of the most celebrated aspects of the series. Characters occasionally get multiple opportunities to prove themselves and work out their aggression, but the opposite is also true. There are some Dragon Ball rematches that would function as major events, but are likely lost causes at this point.  10          Another Fight Between Saiyan Siblings, Goku And Raditz, Isn’t Happening                The bulk of Dragon Ball’s villains have found ways to weasel back into the picture and get another chance at success. However, some of Dragon Ball’s most interesting foes are the fleeting ones that appear at the start of the series. Dragon Ball Z’s first real fight pushes Goku and Piccolo to work together as they take on invading alien, Raditz. Raditz sufficiently showcases Saiyan strength, but the battle is especially emotional since the enemy is Goku’s estranged brother. There’s so much potential in the idea of a rematch between these Saiyan siblings, but this window has likely closed.  9          Bardock Won’t Get A Second Chance To Show His Winning Strategy Over Gas                There are certain rematches between Dragon Ball juggernauts that audiences have been waiting to see for hundreds of episodes, but there are also feuds that are considerably more recent. Gas is Dragon Ball Super’s latest antagonist and the dangerous member of the Heeter Force actually has a curious history with Bardock, Goku’s father. Goku currently struggles to conquer Gas’ power, but it’s something that Bardock was somehow able to accomplish. Bardock’s deceased status makes it highly unlikely that he’ll show up to take out Gas and save the day for Goku.  8          Vegeta And Nappa’s Lengthy History Remains In The Past                Vegeta first appears in Dragon Ball Z as a serious threat to Earth’s future, and it doesn’t take long for a fiery rivalry to form between him and Goku. Vegeta and Goku grow into an iconic Saiyan team, but for years Vegeta engaged in destruction with his partner, Nappa. RELATED: Dragon Ball: 10 Short Fights That Needed To Be Longer Nappa devastates Earth’s weaker heroes, but he’s no match for Goku, which causes Vegeta to cut his losses with the dead weight. Nappa, like Raditz, has mostly remained deceased. An extremely brief reunion between Vegeta and Nappa occurs during Dragon Ball GT’s jailbreak from hell, but it’s unlikely a more substantial rematch ever occurs.  7          An Older Gotenks And Lean Buu Deserve To Duel                Self-improvement isn’t always enough in Dragon Ball, which is where the collaborative process of fusion comes into play. Fusion allows two individuals to combine their strength and abilities into one powerful package. A lot of stock is put on fused fighter, Gotenks, and how he might be strong enough to defeat Buu in his Super Saiyan 3 state. Gotenks isn’t successful, but a helpful version of Buu joins the heroes after the fact. Dragon Ball Super hasn’t done much with Buu, but he briefly gets in shape during his preparation for the Tournament of Power. A new clash of powers between these two would have been a delight.  6          Cabba And Vegeta’s Moment For Collaboration Has Passed                The appearance of a new Saiyan is always reason for celebration in Dragon Ball, but Super goes above and beyond in this regard. Universe 6 and 7 are frequently pitted against each other in competition, which allows Goku and the rest of the universe’s Saiyans to get close with Cabba, Caulifla, and Kale. Cabba exhibits a lot of reverence towards Vegeta’s regal status and is just as interested in training under him as he is in sparring against him. Dragon Ball Super sets up some one-on-one time between these two, but it’s been so long without this promise getting fulfilled that the moment has likely passed.  5          Goku And Pikkon Are The Pride Of The North Quadrant’s Fallen Fighters                A debate rages on between Dragon Ball purists and those who want more incorporation from the anime’s filler material. Pikkon is one of the more popular anime-only characters. The deceased fighter first crosses paths with Goku in the Other World Tournament, where he proves himself as the Super Saiyan’s equal. RELATED: Dragon Ball: 7 Classic Fights That Would Have Been Better With Ki Impressively, Pikkon also plays an important role in the film Fusion Reborn and is a common participant in video games. Many hoped that recruitment for the Tournament of Power would result in an invitation extended out to Pikkon, but Super’s decision to ignore the individual is probably a confirmation that a rematch isn’t happening.  4          Piccolo Won’t Get To Show His Improvement In Another Battle Against Universe 6’s Frost                Piccolo experiences a significant power upgrade on Planet Namek when he fuses with Nail and proves himself against Frieza’s second form. A full-on rematch between Piccolo and Frieza would be incredible after how much they’ve grown, but it’s something that might actually happen with Frieza’s reintegration into the story. Alternatively, Universe 6’s Frieza counterpart, Frost, faces against Piccolo during Universe 7’s tournament against Champa’s best fighters. Frost is fascinating when his intentions are a mystery, but he recedes into the background after he’s exposed as a lesser version of Frieza.  3          A Super Saiyan 4 Showdown Against Anyone Is Extremely Unlikely                Contrary to popular opinion, Dragon Ball GT isn’t a dumpster fire anime sequel. Dragon Ball GT takes some time to find its footing, but it explores some genuinely creative ideas, which unfortunately have largely been undone through the events of Dragon Ball Super. One of Dragon Ball GT’s longest lasting legacies is its unique Super Saiyan 4 transformation. Dragon Ball Super opts for Super Saiyan God and Super Saiyan Blue instead of the GT counterpart, which means that it’s unlikely that there will be a legitimate rematch between any Super Saiyan 4 with anyone (other than in video games and the promotional series, Super Dragon Ball Heroes).  2          Audiences Have Waited Decades For A Gohan And Cell Reunion                Goku usually steals the spotlight when it comes to the elimination of Dragon Ball’s biggest opponents, which is exactly why Gohan’s Super Saiyan 2 debut and subsequent destruction of Cell remains a high point for the series. Gohan has only grown more powerful since his fight against Cell, and it’d make sense if the same was also true for his opponent. There are rumors that Cell makes his grand return in the upcoming movie, Dragon Ball Super: Super Hero, which is the perfect opportunity for a rematch against a grown-up Gohan. This remains wishful thinking and Dragon Ball fans have gotten used to the idea that Cell’s a permanent casualty.  1          Goku And Jiren’s Clash Is The Tournament Of Power’s Apex                Villains of unprecedented power show up in Dragon Ball Super, but the multiversal battle royale competition, the Tournament of Power, becomes the anime’s ultimate test. The strongest warriors from across the multiverse compete in the face of the universes’ potential erasure. Goku and Universe 7 hold their own, but Universe 11’s Jiren quickly proves himself to be Goku’s toughest competition. Jiren’s perseverance and strength pushes Goku to dip into Ultra Instinct power for the first time, which is a milestone for the franchise. Jiren is still alive and he and Goku aren’t on poor terms, but it seems as if Dragon Ball considers Jiren to be in its past. Daniel’s work can be read on ScreenRant, Splitsider, Bloody Disgusting, Den of Geek, and across the Internet. Daniel recently completed work on a noir anthology graphic novel titled, "Sylvia Plath’s The Bell Noir: A Rag of Bizarre Noir and Hard Boiled Tales" and he’s currently toiling away on his first novel. Daniel's extra musings can be found @DanielKurlansky on Twitter. Dragon Ball Super opts for Super Saiyan God and Super Saiyan Blue instead of the GT counterpart, which means that it’s unlikely that there will be a legitimate rematch between any Super Saiyan 4 with anyone (other than in video games and the promotional series, Super Dragon Ball Heroes).  2          Audiences Have Waited Decades For A Gohan And Cell Reunion                Goku usually steals the spotlight when it comes to the elimination of Dragon Ball’s biggest opponents, which is exactly why Gohan’s Super Saiyan 2 debut and subsequent destruction of Cell remains a high point for the series. Gohan has only grown more powerful since his fight against Cell, and it’d make sense if the same was also true for his opponent. There are rumors that Cell makes his grand return in the upcoming movie, Dragon Ball Super: Super Hero, which is the perfect opportunity for a rematch against a grown-up Gohan. This remains wishful thinking and Dragon Ball fans have gotten used to the idea that Cell’s a permanent casualty.  1          Goku And Jiren’s Clash Is The Tournament Of Power’s Apex                Villains of unprecedented power show up in Dragon Ball Super, but the multiversal battle royale competition, the Tournament of Power, becomes the anime’s ultimate test. The strongest warriors from across the multiverse compete in the face of the universes’ potential erasure. Goku and Universe 7 hold their own, but Universe 11’s Jiren quickly proves himself to be Goku’s toughest competition. Jiren’s perseverance and strength pushes Goku to dip into Ultra Instinct power for the first time, which is a milestone for the franchise. Jiren is still alive and he and Goku aren’t on poor terms, but it seems as if Dragon Ball considers Jiren to be in its past. Daniel’s work can be read on ScreenRant, Splitsider, Bloody Disgusting, Den of Geek, and across the Internet. Daniel recently completed work on a noir anthology graphic novel titled, "Sylvia Plath’s The Bell Noir: A Rag of Bizarre Noir and Hard Boiled Tales" and he’s currently toiling away on his first novel. Daniel's extra musings can be found @DanielKurlansky on Twitter. Title: Spy x Family: Twilight's Backstory Reveals His Complicated Relationship With His Father
Data: www.cbr.com                  CBR Exclusives   Comics   Comics News   Comic Features   Comic Previews   Comic Reviews     Movies    Movie News   Movie Features   Movie Reviews     TV    TV News   TV Features   TV Reviews   Wrestling     Anime   Gaming   Lists   Write For CBR   More   CBR Forums   Buyer's Guides   Nerd Culture   Find a Comic Shop       Follow Us   Follow CBR            Something New                    	Covering the hottest movie and TV topics that fans want.                                      	All the latest gaming news, game reviews and trailers.                                      	A one-stop shop for all things video games.                                           Home Anime Spy x Family: Twilight's Backstory Reveals His Complicated Relationship With His Father    Spy x Family: Twilight's Backstory Reveals His Complicated Relationship With His Father  By Hilary Leung Published 17 hours ago     Share    Share    Tweet    Share    Email   Twilight's past before he became the world's best spy comes to light.                  The following contains spoilers for Spy x Family Chapter 62.1 by Tatsuya Endo, Casey Loe and Rina Mapa, available in English now via Viz Media.   In Spy x Family, not much is known about Twilight's past despite the readers having been with him on his family shenanigans and his missions. The only few details that have been revealed are that he abandoned his old life in favor of the life of a spy. Having lost his parents in the war, Twilight's motivation to maintain peace between Westalis and Ostania is so there will not be any other orphans like him. He wanted to create a world where children wouldn't have to cry.  Even though Twilight has no experience being a parent, he is undoubtedly a good father. While he is adamant that the Forger family is nothing but a facade, he nonetheless would be willing to put himself in danger to protect Anya, Yor and Bond. This week's chapter of Spy x Family dives into Twilight's past -- before he was Twilight -- and the events that made him the man he is. RELATED: Why Spy x Family's Plot, Premise & Characters Make the Series So Good                 If there was any hope that readers would get to know Twilight's real name since this chapter focused on his childhood, those hopes were quickly dashed; the chapter cheekily blacked out his name. As a boy, Twilight spent most of his days playing war with his friends in an abandoned depot. He and his friends quickly become infatuated with the idea of being soldiers. At home, however, Twilight immediately hides his toy gun from his father.  Twilight's father is an interesting and rather contradictory character. Upon seeing how eager his son is to go to war to find "those awful monsters from the East," he immediately slaps him. It's not clear if this is a common recurrence, but the fact that his father's first instinct was to hit his son is already concerning. What's more, Twilight's childhood seems to be marred with instances of fights between his mother and father. While the slap is unjustified and should never have been done, his father's anger is understandable. All the sentiments around the Ostanians being "monsters" are propaganda fed by those in Westalis. Instead of hoping for war, Twilight's father says to his son that he should hope for peace.  That's exactly what adult Twilight's mission is -- to maintain peace between Ostania and Westalis so that war doesn't break out. His father's words left a strong enough impact for him to carry that through to his adult life. And although Twilight's father insisted that violence would never achieve peace, Twilight's line of work does demand a certain level of violence in order to protect the powerless. It's not specified, but Twilight's father's job appears to be diplomatic in nature, and he may have worked in a department that maintained peace at the border.  RELATED: Why Spy x Family's Anya Is the Best Girl of the Series                 Knowing who Twilight is now and his occupation, it's endearing to see what he was like when he was a child. Adult Twilight can lie with ease and disguise himself flawlessly in the blink of an eye. Twilight as a boy feels absolutely guilty when he has to lie to his father for pocket money to buy the soldier set. Even after getting the gun, he can't go through with playing with it and returns home. After talking to the croquette lady and realizing that the Ostanians may not be as monstrous as they have been portrayed, Twilight wants to return home and apologize to his father.  Sadly, Twilight doesn't get a chance to do that. A bomb crashes into the town of Luwen, destroying the depot that Twilight's friends were playing in just a few hours ago, leaving nothing but the "KEEP OUT" sign lying in the rubble. The chapter doesn't confirm whether or not Twilight's friends managed to escape before they were killed, but it doesn't look optimistic. Despite having never been a father before, it's made abundantly clear that Twilight's parenting style was influenced by his own father. He would never raise a hand to Anya, and his parenting is usually much more gentle and gives off heartwarming vibes. This is a Twilight who never wants to inflict the same pain on his child (even if Anya is his fake daughter) that he endured when he was young.  It's hard to remember that Spy x Family is set during a time when war could erupt at any moment. All of the comedic moments are what make Spy x Family so enjoyable, but moments like these with Twilight's backstory make readers realize that this is what makes the manga so special.
